title: David Ditzel: worked at Transmeta, now at Intel

inline_content.Text: David Ditzel: worked at Transmeta, now at Intel

title: A 25 year perspective on binary translation: what worked, what didn’t work.

inline_content.Text: A 25 year perspective on binary translation: what worked, what didn’t work.

title: Examples of binary translation:

inline_content.Text: Examples of binary translation:

title: pentium pro and later: translates x86 into internal UOPS via hardware

inline_content.Text: pentium pro and later: translates x86 into internal UOPS via hardware

title: intel ia32el runs user level x86 programs on Itanium with ~60% perf of native machine

inline_content.Text: intel ia32el runs user level x86 programs on Itanium with ~60% perf of native machine

title: Java JITs, .NET (MSIL), VmWare

inline_content.Text: Java JITs, .NET (MSIL), VmWare

title: Apple’s Rosetta runs PowerPC user programs on x86

inline_content.Text: Apple’s Rosetta runs PowerPC user programs on x86

title: Transmeta Crusoe and Efficeon processors - transparent, full system level translation of x86

inline_content.Text: Transmeta Crusoe and Efficeon processors - transparent, full system level translation of x86

title: SYMBOL computer - implemented os, editor etc. in logic gates. Lessons: don’t do that. Use the right combination of software, hardware and micro-ops.

inline_content.Text: SYMBOL computer - implemented os, editor etc. in logic gates. Lessons: don’t do that. Use the right combination of software, hardware and micro-ops.

title: AT&T Crisp:

inline_content.Text: AT&T Crisp:

title: 1987, first CMOS superscalar chip (superscalar: multiple instructions per clock)

inline_content.Text: 1987, first CMOS superscalar chip (superscalar: multiple instructions per clock)

title: Reduced Instruction Set Processor targeted at C

inline_content.Text: Reduced Instruction Set Processor targeted at C

title: hw translated instructions from external, compact version into 180 bit wide UOP cache

inline_content.Text: hw translated instructions from external, compact version into 180 bit wide UOP cache

title:
optimization tricks:
* branch folding - make branches disappear from pipeline
* “Stack Cache” as registers - to reduce memory references

inline_content.Text:
optimization tricks:
* branch folding - make branches disappear from pipeline
* “Stack Cache” as registers - to reduce memory references

title: Lessons from AT&T Crisp:

inline_content.Text: Lessons from AT&T Crisp:

title: translation from external instruction set to internal instruction set works well

inline_content.Text: translation from external instruction set to internal instruction set works well

title: Binary Instrumentation

inline_content.Text: Binary Instrumentation

title: MIPS had tools pixie and pixstats (~1987) to statically modify binaries to count instructions.

inline_content.Text: MIPS had tools pixie and pixstats (~1987) to statically modify binaries to count instructions.

title: Sun followed (~1988) with spix, spixstats etc. Also were able to run MIPS on Sparc (at 1/3rd speed).

inline_content.Text: Sun followed (~1988) with spix, spixstats etc. Also were able to run MIPS on Sparc (at 1/3rd speed).

title: Sun tried to extend Sparc with instructions to help x86 emulation but decided that hw mismatch was too big - Sparc was not the right architecture for this.

inline_content.Text: Sun tried to extend Sparc with instructions to help x86 emulation but decided that hw mismatch was too big - Sparc was not the right architecture for this.

title: Lessons realized in 1995:

inline_content.Text: Lessons realized in 1995:

title: dynamic translation was reaching 1/3 speed of native, static 1/2 of native

inline_content.Text: dynamic translation was reaching 1/3 speed of native, static 1/2 of native

title: processor designed from scratch for binary translation might improve efficiency of dynamic translation by 2-3x

inline_content.Text: processor designed from scratch for binary translation might improve efficiency of dynamic translation by 2-3x

title: full system level binary translation might soon become practical and even exceed perf of standard microprocessor

inline_content.Text: full system level binary translation might soon become practical and even exceed perf of standard microprocessor

title: That led to Transmeta in 1995. Transmeta:

inline_content.Text: That led to Transmeta in 1995. Transmeta:

title: spent $600M over 12 years in R&D

inline_content.Text: spent $600M over 12 years in R&D

title: 5 generations of processors although only 3 announced

inline_content.Text: 5 generations of processors although only 3 announced

title: Key challenges for hybrid processors:

inline_content.Text: Key challenges for hybrid processors:

title: must be 100% compatible. When doing binary translation between commodity processors (e.g. x86<->PowerPC), there are corner cases where emulating things exactly is tricky due to hardware mismatch, which causes inefficiencies in translation => must design for translation

inline_content.Text: must be 100% compatible. When doing binary translation between commodity processors (e.g. x86<->PowerPC), there are corner cases where emulating things exactly is tricky due to hardware mismatch, which causes inefficiencies in translation => must design for translation

title: precise control over user visible state, including precise exception and interrupt semantics

inline_content.Text: precise control over user visible state, including precise exception and interrupt semantics

title: delivered performance, including overhead of translation

inline_content.Text: delivered performance, including overhead of translation

title: Hardware support for hybrid processors:

inline_content.Text: Hardware support for hybrid processors:

title: private, non-volatile storage (FLASH ROM), for storing translation software

inline_content.Text: private, non-volatile storage (FLASH ROM), for storing translation software

title: private memory for storing translated code (stole 5% of DRAM during boot)

inline_content.Text: private memory for storing translated code (stole 5% of DRAM during boot)

title: software controlled state commit/rollback/abort

inline_content.Text: software controlled state commit/rollback/abort

title: more registers than x86

inline_content.Text: more registers than x86

title: alias detection under software control

inline_content.Text: alias detection under software control

title: fine grain detection of self-modifying code

inline_content.Text: fine grain detection of self-modifying code

title: auto-typing of pure memory vs I/O (because I/O can be memory-mapped which prohibits some optimizations)

inline_content.Text: auto-typing of pure memory vs I/O (because I/O can be memory-mapped which prohibits some optimizations)

title: fast traps supported by underlying runtime system

inline_content.Text: fast traps supported by underlying runtime system

title: instruction primitives for fast interpretation

inline_content.Text: instruction primitives for fast interpretation

title: Software controlled atomic execution - execute in temporary space and ability to rollback to previous commit point. Used to perform not-always-safe optimization which are considered ok as long as we hit next commit point without problems. If not, rollback and re-execute without optimizations. Needed to be able to undo stores to memory.

inline_content.Text: Software controlled atomic execution - execute in temporary space and ability to rollback to previous commit point. Used to perform not-always-safe optimization which are considered ok as long as we hit next commit point without problems. If not, rollback and re-execute without optimizations. Needed to be able to undo stores to memory.

title: Transmeta’s code morphing:

inline_content.Text: Transmeta’s code morphing:

title: first level - interpreter

inline_content.Text: first level - interpreter

title: second compiler

inline_content.Text: second compiler

title: translation - it can cost 10000 instructions to translate 1

inline_content.Text: translation - it can cost 10000 instructions to translate 1

title: Efficeon improvements used 4 levels (gears):

inline_content.Text: Efficeon improvements used 4 levels (gears):

title: first level - interpreter 15 instruction per 1, gathers

inline_content.Text: first level - interpreter 15 instruction per 1, gathers

title: after executing basic block 50 uses quick translation (cost 500 instructions per 1 native), also gathers more information

inline_content.Text: after executing basic block 50 uses quick translation (cost 500 instructions per 1 native), also gathers more information

title: after executing more than few hundred times - more optimized translation, more costly, classic optimization like common sub-expression elimination, memory re-ordering, critical path scheduling

inline_content.Text: after executing more than few hundred times - more optimized translation, more costly, classic optimization like common sub-expression elimination, memory re-ordering, critical path scheduling

title: for hot loops, optimize multiple code blocks and use more aggressive optimization

inline_content.Text: for hot loops, optimize multiple code blocks and use more aggressive optimization

title: Lessons: optimization pay off. The bigger the blocks, the bigger optimization payoff.

inline_content.Text: Lessons: optimization pay off. The bigger the blocks, the bigger optimization payoff.

title: Binary translation myths:

inline_content.Text: Binary translation myths:

title: myth: translation is slow. It’s only ~20% overhead

inline_content.Text: myth: translation is slow. It’s only ~20% overhead

title: myth: saving translation to disk is a good idea. In efficeon they improved translation so that it was faster to translate than read from disk

inline_content.Text: myth: saving translation to disk is a good idea. In efficeon they improved translation so that it was faster to translate than read from disk

title: myth: static translation is faster. They compiled Linux kernel to run natively but it was slower than dynamic translation because dynamic translation could use runtime information to optimize.

inline_content.Text: myth: static translation is faster. They compiled Linux kernel to run natively but it was slower than dynamic translation because dynamic translation could use runtime information to optimize.

title: myth: software isn’t reliable. Doesn’t match transmeta’s nor Transiitive’s experience: they didn’t have any x86 compatibility bugs

inline_content.Text: myth: software isn’t reliable. Doesn’t match transmeta’s nor Transiitive’s experience: they didn’t have any x86 compatibility bugs

title: Why binary translation now: power usage since increasing cores requires more power so we might not have enough power to light up all processors at full speed.

inline_content.Text: Why binary translation now: power usage since increasing cores requires more power so we might not have enough power to light up all processors at full speed.
